message: Not necessarily published in 2010, just read then.
Memo to self: don't use A tags in Convore.
Metaprogramming Ruby and Rework: The latter beat the dead horse pretty bad and the former is a must read for increasing your coding efficiency.

In compiling my own list I guess it's more "Favorite non-fiction" than tech-specific: Modern Perl, Rework, Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking, A Short History of Nearly Everything. Also, this post serves as my test to see how Convore handles a post with links in it. ;-)
"Rework" was a good one, I really like "Crush It" by GaryV
@chadspacey really like crush it too, but it just wasn't as relevant to techies

@alexbaldwin understanding social behavior is a big part of the tech, with sites like Convore, which I just learned about a week ago, Twitter and Facebook. Unless "Techies" means only programming. If you make a video game, put up a website or write a blog, understanding why people will visit or buy your game is important. People like Steve Jobs, Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerburg started as "Techies" or "Programmers" but understanding business and social behavior lead them out of the trenches behind a desk. Or I could be wrong. ;-) GaryV really isn't much of a "Techie" anyway.

@chadspacey what I meant was that telling me how to set up a blog and that I should post to it everyday was not a new idea or useful. however, for my mom who is an autism researcher with 100s of pages of notes that doesn't know what a blog is, crush it resonated more for her
I hear ya ;) most of "Crush It" was about stuff I knew already.
"Domain-Driven Design" by Eric Evans. Not exactly new, but one of my most important reads ever.
I read Programming Pearls last year. Best tech book I have read.
Is there a divergent topic for "Books to read in 2011"? :)
Rework, The Social Network and Using JRuby
